an8.22:3.1: 22 With Ugga of the Village of Hatthi
an8.22:4.1: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Vajjians at the village of Hatthi.
an8.22:4.2: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants:
an8.22:4.3: “Mendicants, you should remember the householder Ugga of Hatthi as someone who has eight amazing and incredible qualities.”
an8.22:4.4: This is what the Buddha said.
an8.22:4.5: When he had spoken, the Holy One got up from his seat and entered his dwelling.
an8.22:5.1: Then a certain mendicant got dressed in the morning and, taking his bowl and robes, went to the home of the householder Ugga of Hatthi,
an8.22:5.2: where he sat on the indicated seat.
an8.22:5.3: Then Ugga of Hatthi went up to that mendicant,
an8.22:5.4: bowed, and sat down to one side.
an8.22:5.6: “Householder, the Buddha declared that you have eight amazing and incredible qualities.
an8.22:5.7: What are the eight qualities that he spoke of?”
an8.22:6.2: what eight amazing and incredible qualities the Buddha was referring to.
an8.22:6.3: But these eight amazing and incredible qualities are found in me. Listen and pay close attention,
an8.22:6.7: “Sir, when I first saw the Buddha off in the distance I was partying in the Dragon’s Park.
an8.22:6.8: My heart was inspired as soon as I saw him, and I sobered up.
an8.22:6.9: This is the first incredible and amazing quality found in me.
an8.22:7.1: With confident heart I paid homage to the Buddha.
an8.22:7.2: The Buddha taught me step by step, with
an8.22:7.3: talk on giving, ethical conduct, and heaven.
an8.22:7.4: He explained the drawbacks of sensual pleasures, so sordid and corrupt, and the benefit of renunciation.
an8.22:7.5: And when he knew that my mind was ready, pliable, rid of hindrances, joyful, and confident he explained the special teaching of the Buddhas:
an8.22:7.6: suffering, its origin, its cessation, and the path.
an8.22:7.7: Just as a clean cloth rid of stains would properly absorb dye,
an8.22:7.8: in that very seat the spotless, immaculate vision of the Dhamma arose in me:
an8.22:7.9: ‘Everything that has a beginning has an end.’
an8.22:7.10: I saw, attained, understood, and fathomed the Dhamma. I went beyond doubt, got rid of indecision, and became self-assured and independent of others regarding the Teacher’s instructions. Right there I went for refuge to the Buddha, his teaching, and the Saṅgha. And I undertook the five training rules with celibacy as the fifth.
an8.22:7.11: This is the second incredible and amazing quality found in me.
an8.22:8.4: ‘Sisters, I’ve undertaken the five training rules with chastity as fifth.
an8.22:8.5: If you wish, you may stay here, enjoy my wealth, and do good deeds. Or you can return to your own families.
an8.22:8.6: Or would you prefer if I gave you to another man?’
an8.22:8.7: When I said this, my eldest wife said to me:
an8.22:8.8: ‘My lord, please give me to such-and-such a man.’
an8.22:8.9: Then I summoned that man. Taking my wife with my left hand and a ceremonial vase with my right, I presented her to that man with the pouring of water.
an8.22:8.10: But I can’t recall getting upset while giving away my teenage wife .
an8.22:8.11: This is the third incredible and amazing quality found in me.
an8.22:9.1: And though my family has wealth,
an8.22:9.2: it’s shared without reserve with ethical people of good character.
an8.22:9.3: This is the fourth incredible and amazing quality found in me.
an8.22:10.1: When I pay homage to a mendicant,
an8.22:10.2: I do so carefully, not carelessly.
an8.22:10.3: If that venerable teaches me the Dhamma,
an8.22:10.5: But if they don’t teach me the Dhamma, I teach them.
an8.22:10.6: This is the fifth incredible and amazing quality found in me.
an8.22:11.1: It’s not unusual for gods to come to me when the Saṅgha has been invited and announce:
an8.22:11.2: ‘Householder, that mendicant is freed both ways. That one is freed by wisdom. That one is a direct witness. That one is attained to view. That one is freed by faith. That one is a follower of principles. That one is a follower by faith. That one is ethical, of good character. That one is unethical, of bad character.’
an8.22:11.3: But while I’m serving the Saṅgha I don’t recall thinking:
an8.22:11.4: ‘Let me give this one just a little, and that one a lot.’
an8.22:11.6: This is the sixth incredible and amazing quality found in me.
an8.22:12.1: It’s not unusual for gods to come to me and announce:
an8.22:12.2: ‘Householder, the Buddha’s teacher is well explained!’
an8.22:12.3: When they say this I say to them:
an8.22:12.4: ‘The Buddha’s teaching is well explained, regardless of whether or not you gods say so!’
an8.22:12.5: But I don’t recall getting too excited by the fact that
an8.22:12.6: the gods come to me, and I have a conversation with them.
an8.22:12.7: This is the seventh incredible and amazing quality found in me.
an8.22:13.1: If I pass away before the Buddha, it wouldn’t be surprising if the Buddha declares of me:
an8.22:13.2: ‘The householder Ugga of Hatthi is bound by no fetter that might return him to this world.’
an8.22:13.3: This is the eighth incredible and amazing quality found in me.
an8.22:14.1: These eight amazing and incredible qualities are found in me.
an8.22:14.3: what eight amazing and incredible qualities the Buddha was referring to.”
an8.22:15.1: Then that mendicant, after taking alms-food in Ugga of Hatthi’s home, got up from his seat and left.
an8.22:15.2: Then after the meal, on his return from alms-round, he went to the Buddha,
an8.22:15.3: bowed, and sat down to one side.
an8.22:15.4: He informed the Buddha of all he had discussed with the householder Ugga of the village of Hatthi. The Buddha said:
an8.22:16.2: When I declared that the householder Ugga of the village of Hatthi was someone who has eight amazing and incredible qualities, I was referring to the same eight qualities that he rightly explained to you.
an8.22:16.3: You should remember the householder Ugga of Hatthi as someone who has these eight amazing and incredible qualities.”
